reviewText: I actually saw this movie before I read the book.  I really enjoyed the movie, although there were parts that were shockingly violent and gratuitous.  However, after being inspired to read the book, I went back and re-watched the movie.  This movie did to its book counterpart the same thing that Ron Howard did to "Angels and Demons": The underlying plot was basically the same, but the main characters and supporting points were drastically altered.  To name just a few:1) In the original story, Mikael is supposed to be working for Henrik under the auspice of writing a Vanger family history, so as not to arouse suspicion about his investigation.  In the movie, his investigation into the disappearance/murder of Harriet is plain knowledge to everyone from the moment he is hired.2) In the original story, Mikael discovered Lisbeth's prior hacking into his computer on his own, due to a slip from Dirch Frode and a mistake by Lisbeth in her research report.  In the movie, this got changed to Lisbeth basically revealing herself to Mikael by sending him an unencrypted e-mail that solved the mystery of the "phone numbers" (in the original story, this mystery was actually solved by a comment from Mikael's daughter).  This may not seem like a big point, but it completely changed the dynamic of Mikael and Lisbeth's first meeting (it made the scene far less playful on Mikael's part, and far less astounded on Lisbeth's part).3) Mikael is supposed to be an attractive ladies man (having separate affairs with Erika, Cecilia, and Lisbeth over the course of the book) with a good heart.  The way they portrayed him in this movie made him look like a lost puppy pining for Lisbeth after she has sex with him for the first time.4) Lisbeth is supposed to have far more emotional depth than simply being a tough, introverted, slightly imbalanced goth girl.  I feel like Noomi Rapace did a good job with the script she was given, but the script itself didn't allow for much more than a superficial look into Lisbeth's character.5) In the original story, Mikael and Lisbeth end up discovering that Martin is the killer at the same time, but at different locations and from different angles.  The movie makes it that Mikael comes to the wrong conclusion (thinking that Harald is the killer) and then is captured by Martin, while Lisbeth is the only one to come to the correct conclusion.  This makes Mikael look like far less competent of an investigative journalist than his character was original made to be.There are several more examples, but I won't bore you with them.  My advice is to enjoy the movie or enjoy the book, but you will probably be disappointed in one or the other if you try to do both.
summary: A good movie by itself, but not a good adaptation of a great book.

reviewText: I've never read Stieg Larsson's novel 'Girl with the Dragon Tattoo', so I have no idea how close this film follows it's source material. I will say that this movie is one of the more entertaining thrillers to come out in recent years. While most american studios seem to reserve material like this for TV series, 'Girl with the Dragon Tattoo' along with 2008's 'Tell No One' show that the procedural/thriller genre can still make a strong movie-going experience.'Girl with the Dragon Tattoo' is about disgraced investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist who's been hired by an old rich industrialist to investigate the 40 year old disappearance of his foster child, who also happened to be someone Mikael knew as a child. Mikael ends up teaming with Lisbeth Salander a security consoltant and hacker and they both end up digging up secrets and a violent family history. The story very much plays out like a mystery novel, first introducing some character backgrounds (Mikael is facing jail time for losing a libel case, Lisbeth is a loner and sexually/physically abused by men in her life) then slowly introduces us to the suspects and then mostly follows Mikael and Lisbeth as they do internet and record searches to slowly uncover decades-long conspiracies as well as a serial killer.What I like most about 'Girl with the Dragon Tattoo' is the seemingly normal charcters and setting. Michael Nyqvist is perfect as Mikael looking exactly how you'd picture a middle-aged, out of shape journalist. Noomi Rapace is equally well chosen as Lisbeth while (even in nude scenes) not looking too sexy but not ugly by any means either. Even when both characters are dealing with larger-than-life situations and their slightly budding attraction to each other neither one loses their credibility nor believability. I also loved that the characters were using real software and search engines like 'Google' to look up information.If I have a complaint with this film it's probably with the background and abuse of the Lisbeth character. While Mikael's personal connection to the case keeps us rooting for him Lisbeth's motivations seem to keep changing on the fly. I realise this makes her a bit more complex (and lets face it she IS the title character) it seems the more we find out about her the less interesting or more confusing she becomes. I felt terrible for what happens to her character (and couldn't help myself rooting for her getting her revenge on her abusive legal guardian) but I also found her hard to like at points to. Maybe I'm just getting sick of stories (usually written by men) that feel the only way to have a strong female character is to put her through the physical/sexual abuse wringer. It makes sense with the story's theme of violence against women but again I found it a bit hard to swallow.While the violence in 'Girl with the Dragon Tattoo' is far from exploitive, it can be hard to take at points. There are a scenes involving rape (though thankfully don't last very long) and instances of body mutilation (post mordem). Like I said none of these scenes are explict but they can be disturbing to watch.Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is an excellent suspense film. If you liked thrillers like 'Tell No One' or are just itching for a good 'who-done-it' mystery this movie is a must see.

reviewText: Here's an anomaly: Scandinavian noir that mostly takes place in the sunshine or well-lit interiors, Niels Arden Oplev, who directed this version of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, gets high marks for his gutsy re-shaping of the genre. The film also provides standout performances by lead actors Michael Nyqvist and Noomi Rapace (for which Opley probably deserves some credit, as well). Stunning cinematography by Eric Kess and Jens Fischer add to the mix.But there's a drawback. The film suffers by adhering much too closely to the Steig Larsson novel. On the screen, the story becomes impossibly sprawling, with so many plot details that the movie chugs along sluggishly, finally clocking in at more than two and half hours. Misdirected efforts to shave a few seconds here and there -- like having witnesses almost instantly find forty-year-old evidence -- cut a little screen time, but at the price of weakening the film's credibility. A crucial mistake was the unfortunate choice by the director and screenwriters Nikolaj Arcel and Rasmus Heisterbergand to lavish extensive screen time on the most extravagantly violent aspects of the story. By the time we reach the dramatic climax in the killer's lair, this lurid overload practically begs for parody.The film would have been far more effective if the story line had been trimmed, assorted unnecessary subplots dropped, and the violence subdued so that key plot twists could shine through.If you're a fan of Larsson's novels, you may well enjoy this film. If you're coming at it more as a film buff, you'll likely appreciate its acting and cinematography. But as a whole, you'll probably find it too long, over-the-top, and irritating.
summary: great performances, beautiful photography, but script and direction absurdly lurid

reviewText: The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo is not as my husband believes, a chick flick.  Nor is it for the faint of heart or squeamish.  It is a thriller of the most thrilling kind. reviewText: Ladies and Gentlemen, do I have a movie for you. It's called "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo."Like Ali used to say, I'm a poet and don't know it."The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" is a Swedish-made movie with English subtitles, but don't think for a moment that "Made in Sweden" is the stamp of an inferior movie. This one rivets you from the very start, and not once during the 2 hour and 35 minute movie did I think it was dragging and running much too long. Since being released in Sweden in 2009, and in America in 2010, "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" is already the highest grossing Swedish movie of all time."The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo," which was brilliantly directed by Niels Arden Oplev, is based on the first of a trilogy of novels by Stieg Larsson novel entitled "Men Who Hate Woman." That fact is horribly evident, as in this movie, woman are brutalized and killed, and in one scene, horribly raped. Most of the murders, and there were a sting of them spanning 55 years, are discovered after the fact, and it isn't until the movie's surprise ending that we fully realize the scope of the atrocities.The movie starts with the trial of Mikael Blomkvist (Michael Nyqvist), a journalist who works for the powerhouse magazine Millennium. Blomkvist is falsely convicted of libel against a corrupt Swedish industrialist, and he and the magazine are ordered to pay damages, while Blomkvist is ordered to serve 6-9 months in prison. While waiting to serve his sentence, Blomkvist is approached by Henrik Vanger, the eighty-something member of the wealthy Vanger Group, to find the murder of his niece Harriet some forty years earlier, when she was only 16. What makes things more spicy, is that her body was never found, and we're left with the impression in the back of our minds that maybe she isn't really dead after all.After he begins his investigation, Blomkvist realizes he's being followed, photographed and his computer hacked by punk rocker (complete with dual nose rings) Lisbeth Salander, played by Swedish/Spanish actress Noomi Raspeth, in one of the most memorable female performances of the past 25 years. Lisbeth is an expert hacker, who has a troubled past and who may have even set her own father on fire, to stop his sexual advances.During the course of the movie, she gets beaten up by a gang of punks, has a lesbian scene with her lover and is forced to perform oral sex on her evil probation guardian. Then on her next visit to him, he brutally rapes her, in a scene that made my hair stand straight on end. But good triumphs over evil (well, sort of) when Lisbeth exacts her revenge in a scene so deliciously brutal and visually satisfying, a rousing round of applause was in order and was gladly given.As the plot begins to unfold, Lisbeth sends Blomkvist anonymous clues to help him find the truth about the disappearance of Vander's niece, and soon they are both working together, sleeping together (there's one great sex scene), and fighting the forces of evil together. He gets brutally beaten, shot at and grazed in the cheek, and finally hung from his neck by a pulley manned by the movie's ultimate bad guy. Lisbeth rides to his rescue, on a motorcycle of course, and saves the day. After getting Blomkvist's neck out of the noose, she chases the bad guy in his car until he crashes. Then she watches him pleaded for help (as she smirks), and his overturned car goes up in flames. Oops and Ka-Boom!The movie doesn't end here and we are treated to another half hour of tension, as the murders of scores of women, dating back to Hitler's days, are uncovered and explained.Already an American version of "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" is in the works, but I can't imagine any other actress playing the part of Lisbeth. Yet Rapace said she has already withdrawn herself from consideration for the American movie."I lived in Lisbeth's body and mind for 18 months," Repace said in a recent interview. "I want her out of my life so I can get on with my life.""The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" was universally lauded, with special kudos given to Repace.Jason Zingale, movie reviewer for the website Bullz-eye.com, said, "It should come as no surprise that Noomi Repace has become the face of the franchise, because she is nothing short of magnificent in the buzz-worthy role. The gorgeous Swedish actress is virtually unrecognizable as the tortured hacker who looks, as Larsson writes 'as though she has just emerged from a week-long orgy with a gang of hard rockers.' The much talked about rape scene involving Lisbeth (and the events that follow it) pretty much guarantees that every young actress in Hollywood will be campaigning for the part in David Fincher's American remake."Too bad Angelina Jolie is pushing 40. If she were 10-15 years younger, she'd be perfect for the part. But then again with today's makeup.........."The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" is such a fabulous movie, that on a one to five star basis, I give it a full five stars. This movie is so outstanding, I can't help but think I'll be disappointed by the soon-to-be-made American version.

reviewText: "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo", a book by Stieg Larsson, that I greatly enjoyed and reviewed for Amazon, has spawned a movie version that is extremely well done and is a very faithful rendering of the book. It's in Swedish with English subtitles. If you haven't read the book, the film is a standalone, a very clear film which doesn't require a reading of the novel. It's a very intense, gripping movie that, I think, is going to grab and hold you.Magazine owner and investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist, has been found guilty of libeling a big industrial magnate and is sentenced to three months in prison. He has to take a leave from his magazine, and while he's waiting to serve his sentence, he is hired by wealthy industrialist Henrik Vanger to find out who in his family murdered his niece, Harriet Vanger, forty years before. Some of the Vanger family, a mean and nasty bunch, live on a private island with him.Mikael moves to the island and later joins forces in the investigation with the tattooed girl. The girl of the title, Lisbeth Salender is very strange with piercings on her face, and she wears very severe-looking tight-fitting jeans and jacket. Her make-up is stark, and she seems menacing and creepy as well as beautiful. She's a computer hacker who investigates cases for a security agency. She can get information that few others can dig up. The investigative techniques and the research procedures are handled very well in this movie. It's fascinating to watch her and Mikael delve into family secrets. Some members of the Vanger family were Nazi sympathizers.The violent, torture and s and m scenes in this movie are almost unbearable to watch, so beware. This is definitely not a movie for the kiddies. Mikael gets deeply involved in the investigation and at one point, he gets shot. Serial killings, mutilations, and serious cases of abuse come up during the probing, and devastating family secrets are brought to light. Flashbacks add to the suspense.The acting in the film is excellent, and the cinematography is outstanding with some sweeping views of the austere Swedish landscape.The book and its two sequels have become international bestsellers, and this movie has been a considerable hit in the world market. Two movie sequels are due soon. It's fitting that the original title of this book was "Men Who Hate Women." Lisbeth is a victim who knows how to mete out vengeance.
summary: A Perfect Rendering of a Fascinating Book

reviewText: Just as Sam Spade was emblematic of his times so is Lisbeth Salander in "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo." The more things change the more they stay the same. Where Spade was liable to slap around a suspect to get information, Lisbeth just as easily hacks the suspects computer. Lisbeth Salander is a new detective for a new century."The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" follows the plot of the Stieg Larsson's novel of the same name. Michael Blomkvist (Michael Nyquist) and Lisbeth Salander (Noomi Rapace) search for the killer of Harriet Vanger and in the doing so reveal disturbing family secrets that include Nazi's, incest, murder, and mutilations. The movie trims off the excess of the novel and brings to the screen the core of the story. A fast moving noir thriller that will keep you glued to the screen. Where the movie deviates from the book it is either to omit subplots or information that doesn't add to the solution of who murdered Harriet. There are a couple of instances where they screenwriters (Nikolaj Arcel, Rasmus Heisterberg) have changed minor details but in the end when the puzzle is fit together it all makes sense.Director Niels Oplev does a good job of bringing all the elements together. A lot of the expository scenes come together as montages and the information to know who is who is  disseminated quickly. Noomi Rapace looks hard and feral as Lisbeth, a woman with a dark past that is only briefly seen in flashback, and a dark present that she deals with on her own terms.The eternal debate of the book or the movie being better probably won't be solved because the book and the movie are different experiences. For fans of the book the movie may seem like a streamlined film that hits all the highlights of the book. For a movie-goer that hasn't read the book, it'll seem like a well made thriller.Bonus Features. The DVD only has a few bonus features, a Vanger family tree, a trailer for "The Girl Who Played with Fire" (the next chapter in the trilogy) and most interestingly a 15 minute interview with Noomi Rapace on her experience of playing Lisbeth Salander.
summary: A New Kind of Detective for A New Century

reviewText: THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO based on the Swedish novel MEN WHO HATE WOMEN is an intensely engaging film. At 2 1/2 hours, it might seem that the film would be impossibly, indigestably long. In Swedish with subtitles (there is an English language track), it might seem impenetrable. None of that is the case. I watched it through, in Swedish, and never once glanced at my watch.This is a dark film, but it avoids the lugubrious plodding of the typical Ingmar Bergman film, and it avoids the gratuitous hyperintellectualized symbolism of a typical art house piece. In pacing and material, this film has much more in common withThe Silence Of The LambsthanThe Hour of the Wolf.Noomi Rapace plays Goth Girl Lisbeth Salander, a gifted hacker but deeply scarred young woman who works as a Private Investigator's researcher. Lisbeth, who has a history of psychiatric disturbance, is on probation. At the film's outset, she is assigned a new Guardian (a State appointed Probation Officer/Conservator), who brutally rapes her when she meets with him to request her stipend. Lisbeth, with the hardness that only the truly injured can have, retaliates against her tormentor in a grimly satisfying exhibition of sadomasochistic glee, after which she betakes herself back to her own world.Rapace's portrayal of the tattooed, pierced, troubled Lisbeth is so compelling and realistic that I received a slight shock to discover how normative Noomi Rapace appears in the DVD's brief "Special Features" interview segment.Michael Lindqvist plays Mikael Blomqvist, an investigative reporter convicted of defaming a major government official. Despite the fact that it is quite clear that Blomqvist was set up, he has no option but to serve his sentence, deferred for six months. Unable to work for his paper, he is hired by Henrik Vanger, the paterfamilias of a powerful, clannish, but extremely dysfunctional family of industrialists, most of whom live on a private island. Vanger's beloved niece, Harriet, vanished forty years before, and no one has been able to trace her whereabouts. Vanger is convinced that Harriet was murdered, more than likely by a member of the family.Mikael begins to investigate. In the process, he allies himself with Lisbeth. Although most of the Vangers try to dissuade the pair from accomplishing anything substantive, it quickly becomes evident that the Vanger clan is riddled with rot and evil, including membership in the Swedish Nazi Party and a fearful history of domestic abuse and violence, culminating in what appears to be a number of unsolved serial murders.The violence and darkness of THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO is indisputable and graphic, but it is not gratuitous. This is not a "slasher" film, it is a profound psychodrama and pursuit thriller. It is definitely not family fare, not for the young and impressionable, or for the faint of heart nor the easily distraught, but there is nothing dishonest or excessive about its portrayals.Many reviewers have criticized the film's expressed violence toward women, but such violence is an all-too terrible fact of life in many quarters. The women, too, are not simply victims. Lisbeth, as the eponymous Girl With The Dragon Tattoo, is an unconventional but powerful character, portrayed powerfully, and the other female roles in the film are likewise portrayals of strong women. If anything, the men in THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO are the weaker, less competent, less emotionally, intellectually and psychologically stable sex.This film is not for everybody. However, if you are a cinemaphile, it is an experience that should not be missed.VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED***Having since seen the Director's Cut of the trilogy (which adds a full two-and-a-half hours, the equivalent of an entire movie, to the tale of Lisbeth Salander), I will recommend the Director's cut wholeheartedly. It makes all three movies five star offerings---at the very least.

reviewText: It's a rare occurrence when the film version can adequately capture the essence of the best selling book on which it's based, but, that's exactly what happened with this version of The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo. Noomi Rapace and Michael Nyqvist are perfectly cast as Lisbeth and Blomkvist. They've had to ditch a lot of detail, and compress a lot of the action, of course, but that takes nothing away from the suspense of the original story. The supporting characters at Millenium, Blomqvist's left wing magazine, are given short shrift, so if you want background info on his life, you'll have to read the book. But Lisbeth is the quintessential victim turned avenger; she's a computer genius who's actually made me wish I could be a hacker half as good as she is. But as for the rest of her young life - it's been a nightmare, and it's no stretch to understand how she got where she is. The theme of this thriller revolves around the violence that men do to women and girls, and the governmental bureaucracy that, inadvertently - or not - allows it. Blomqvist is the archetypal champion of human rights, the journalist dedicated to exposing corruption wherever it rears its head, and he and Lisbeth play off each others' strengths and motivations.This is a film that carries enormous cultural significance, and it's difficult to imagine that American film makers can improve upon the Swedish version. See it, and if it moves you, read the book, or better yet, the series.

reviewText: Unless you've been hiding out under a rock, you've probably heard of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, written by the late Swedish journo-novelist Stieg Larsson.  The conclusion to the book trilogy, The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets' Nest, just came out earlier this year.  All three novels are international sensations, and I admit, I bought a copy of the opening number to see what all the fuss was about.  But, as it goes, I never got to read it, and now I'm not sure if I ever will.In 2009, a Swedish version of the movie was released.  Like its source material, the film received excellent reviews.  Performance-wise, Michael Nyqvist (Mikael) and Noomi Rapace (Lisbeth) both acted their characters perfectly, so I've read.  The tone of the movie was on par with the book, and all around it's grossed loads of money, if you want to measure success that way.  Knowing that Hollywood would be releasing a (likely dreaded) adaptation soon, I decided to rent the foreign film and watch it on Friday night.  (The movie is in Swedish, but subtitled in English.)The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is a layered story.  Chiefly, journalist Mikael, recently indicted on several accounts of libel, is contacted by the wealthy entrepreneur Henrik Vanger.  Forty years ago, Henrik's niece, Harriet, vanished, and ever since then Henrik's obsessed over her disappearance.  He hires Mikael to try and uncover what happened to her.  Meanwhile, Lisbeth Salander, a modern-day punk with a troubled past, has been hired to hack into Mikael's computer and keep track of him.  Eventually the two's paths cross and from there the film evolves.The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo 2 This summary is a rough review at best.  There are several things going on throughout the movie, and the disappearance of Harriet Vanger takes the back burner.  The list of suspects is large, and the film takes time to investigate most.  In America, this stuff would largely be overlooked, I think.  Hollywood seems too bent on churning out action and memorable climaxes that not enough time is spent on the rising action.  In Sweden's movie industry, at least with this film, this is not the case.  The plot slowly unravels, inviting the viewer to learn more about the protagonists and their lives.  The whole time I was wondering what happened to Lisbeth in her past?  Is Mikael as "good" as he's portrayed?  Characterization is truly the main driving force behind the movie.Lisbeth is a highly fascinating character.  Immediately you can tell she's got something going on with her.  She comes across as cold and uncaring to nearly everyone.  She's obviously smart, being her career choice, but how smart?  She's a character with a past that's strongly affecting her every action, and I was interested to explore her more.  Add Mikael to the mix, who's a bit more open to conversation, and dynamic between the two is amusing.Stylistically, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is a dark film.  Part of this comes from Lisbeth's wardrobe.  Part from the cold, deadly grip of Sweden's winter.  Most of it's from the darkness that's becoming more apparent as each minute ticks by.  Incredible acts of violence, some very graphic, and you can't help but feel a pang in your gut.  By the end of the movie, I remarked how sick and disgusting some things were, and Keisha agreed.  Yet, despite this grisly nature, the movie is great.  The real world is not peaches and sunshine.  It's not hard to imagine every dark action taking place outside of the film, and it's a tragedy that such things happen in our world.  The movie is graphic, as I've said, and borderline Realistic, but that culminates in making the film even better.After watching The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, I can't help but wonder how the final two books pan out.  What's in store for the two fascinating protagonists?  Furthermore, I wonder now if it's even worth reading the book after watching the film.  What was omitted?  Would a Wikipedia summary suffice?  I'm not sure, and if any of you could tell me, let me know.  Overall, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo was an exceptional movie, filled with mystery, tension, and unforgettable characters.  It's dark, but in my opinion there's enough light shining through the shadow to make it worth your while.  If you're going to watch it, I'd recommend doing this version instead of waiting for the Hollywood atrocity that's bound to happen.
summary: An Exceptional Film with Memorable Characters

reviewText: This movie is the first in the trilogy based on the novels by Stieg Larsson.  It is the original movie, in Swedish with subtitles, directed by Niels Arden Oplev.  It runs 2.5 hours but the film flies by as it keeps you glued to the screen.  This film does not do the book justice but what movie version does?  If you liked the movie, I highly recommend the book with the same titleThe Girl with the Dragon Tattoo.  Those who read the book first might be disappointed with the male lead (the US version with Craig Daniels is much closer to the mark) as he is suppose to be a heartthrob but it's a matter of personal taste.The two actors who play the lead characters Lisbeth Salander (Noomi Rapace) and Mikael Blomkvist (Michael Nyqvist) remain through the film trilogy which is nice.  All three original Swedish movies are available and although they might be hard to find, are worth it.  There are three versions of this film: (1) 142 minutes (released in the UK); (2) 153 minutes (this film); and the extended version of 180 minutes.  I think the extended version is only available in Swedish and I have no idea what the differences are between them.  The series has become such a hit that an American version is in the works for a 2012 release.Noomi Rapace plays Lisbeth exactly as I pictured when reading the novel.  There is no Hollywood casting here and the movie shines brighter for it.  I will not summarize the plot in fear of giving too much away except to note that the original Swedish title "Men Who Hate Women" is very fitting.  This movie is emotionally visceral as we are forced to watch Lisbeth being debased by her new parole officer.  Although this movie contains graphic images of brutal murders and adult subject matter, it was necessary in telling this very compelling story.It centers around Blomkvist, a journalist, who is trying to solve a 40 year murder case involving a very rich and influential Swedish family.  Dark family secrets involving ties to the Nazi party were always whispered about but Blomkvist uncovers more then the family bargained for as he searches for the truth with the help of Lisbeth.  The results are edge of your seat moments until the viewer sits back in horror when the truth is discovered.  I had a slight problem with their prime suspect being a young man who was too fuzzy in a photo to identify and when the resulting suspect did not fit the criteria, it took Blomkvist too long to catch on.The true star of this film is the character of Lisbeth.  She is mysterious and intriguing.  This movie contains the perfect intro to the next in the series - The Girl Who Played with Fire.  I highly recommend this film to anyone who enjoys a great thriller.

reviewText: Over 2.5 million people in Scandinavia have seen this film, making it the first film in Scandinavian history ever to break the $100 million mark for European ticket sales, and US fans of Stieg Larsson's bestseller of the same name may propel the film to similar records here.  The R-rated film tells the story of Mikael Blomqvist, a disgraced journalist for Sweden's Millenium magazine who accepts an invitation from an elderly businessman to investigate the disappearance of his niece Harriet, thirty-seven years ago. No trace of her has ever turned up, and the old man fears that a member of his family may have murdered her.  While Blomquist is gathering information and storing it on his computer, he realizes that someone is hacking into his files.  That person is Lizbeth Salander, a disturbed young woman living under the guardianship of the state, having spent time in a mental institution.  Working together, they discover information about the Vanger family's Nazi connections and their association with extreme religious groups.Danish director Niels Arden Oplev's dark and atmospheric cinematography establishes an ice-cold mood from the outset, with the action taking place in winter on an isolated island where the sun never seems to shine.  Outdoor scenes are mostly black, white, and gray;  interior scenes are full of clutter and of dark wood of almost claustrophobic heaviness.  Michael Nyqvist (as Mikael Blomqvist) conveys the sense of loss, even betrayal, that his character feels after losing a libel case in a miscarriage of justice, and his vulnerability makes him the perfect foil for Noomi Rapace (as Lizbeth Salander).  Rapace conveys not only the toughness and emotional dissociation resulting from abuse Lizbeth has faced, but also, in two memorable scenes, the feeling that behind the seemingly ironclad faade, there beats a real heart.  Her role in the film is bigger than it is in the novel, and when she is on screen, it is impossible to look at anyone else.  Nyqvist seems to recognize this, conveying Blomqvist's support for her through body language, gesture, and facial expressions, and remaining more in the background.  The supporting actors, though their parts are far less developed, are equally committed to the film as a whole.Brilliant pacing keeps the action and its shocks continuing throughout the film, and not a single "dead spot" appears, an extraordinary feat for a film that is more than two-and-a-half hours long and depends upon subtitles for dialogue.  Even people familiar with the book will be jolted by the sudden visual shocks as they hit.  Horrifying scenes of physical and sexual violence often make the film very difficult to watch, the sounds of the violence making the visual effects even stronger.  There are some scenes of nudity.Every aspect of this film is integrated into the whole, however, and it is difficult to imagine any adult fan of the book being disappointed in this production.  The Girl Who Played with Fire and The Girl who Kicked the Hornet's Nest, the remaining two books in the trilogy, have already been filmed and released to huge audiences in Europe, and both of these films are projected for release in the US (with subtitles) in the fall of 2010. reviewText: I was blown away by Niel Arden Oplev's film adaptation of Larsson's book, and especially intrigued by the character of Lisbeth Salander.  As Roger Ebert commented in his recent movie review, the character of Lisbeth Salander, is more fascinating & interesting than the story itself.  Salander is an extremely intelligent and resourceful young woman who possesses exceptional capabilities and displays a fierce determination to bring men who abuse women to justice.  As a deeply wounded person who was the victim of rape and violence, she finds it very difficult to express herself in words but she communicates by action.  The partnership that Lisbeth has with Mikael Blomkvist is a very interesting relationship -- both are forced into this relationship, they learn to respect and care for each other but are afraid to express their emotions openly.The story line involves Mikael Blomkvist, the reporter of the Millennium magazine, and Lisbeth Salander, the intelligent & antisocial researcher hired by Milton Security, teaming up to find out what happened to Harriet Vanger, beloved niece of the billionaire Henrik Vanger, who vanished in 1966.  Henrik Vanger hires Blomkvist and later on, Blomkvist enlists the help of Salander, to investigate the large Vanger family and to find out the truth of what happened to Harriet and who or what is responsible for her disappearance.Much of the success of this movie goes to the gifted director Niels Arden Oplev, who initially turned down the project but who was convinced later on by the producer Soren Staermose to do the project on condition that he was given complete artistic control over cast, script, length, editing, etc.  His artistic style shows in every aspect of the movie.  The characters come to life, there is visual poetry as Lisbeth Salander and Mikael Blomkist do the research on the Vanger family tree and the clues begin to emerge.  The pacing of the movie is excellent and the movie builds to a satisfying climax and resolution.Much credit goes to the outstanding actress Noomi Rapace for embodying and bringing the Salander character to life in this excellent first film adaptation.  One of the wonderful special features in this DVD is the extensive interview with Noomi Rapace where she discusses how she was able to transform herself to play and embody the Salander character, how she figured out how to play Lisbeth, what life was like in the 1 1/2 years she spent in playing the role in the Trilogy, and how she felt about playing the character.  The Special Features also provide a preview of The Girl Who Played With Fire, and a diagram of the Vanger Family Tree.As I watched this movie, I felt that it was a Swedish equivalent of the American thriller, "The Silence of the Lambs", which came out 11 years ago.  Both films feature a gifted female protagonist with a wounded past who is extremely intelligent and gifted; both of these women solve a complicated  mystery that involves a vicious killer.  Lisbeth Salander is one of the most intriguing and interesting characters to come in a very long time, both in literature and in film.(Warning: This movie contains scenes of brutality and rape vs. women)This is one of the best suspense-thrillers in recent years.

reviewText: It is very rare to watch a movie based on a favorite book and not be disappointed. THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO, however, is a rare exception as it is a perfect adaptation. German and French (to to mention American) audiences, to name but a few, have been addicted to hearing their own language. This convenience, although it can work for most blockbusters, it rubs off all the subtle details that give rise to a masterpiece.Noomi Rapace simply IS Lisbeth Salander. The body-type, the attitude, the self-assured distrust towards the world. From the way she enters a room to the way she hits her computer keys she is possessed by Lisbeth's spirit.In this first installment of the Millennium Trilogy Mikael Blomkvist (Michael Nyqvist) and his investigation form the center of gravity. No matter, the moment Lisbeth enters a scene she steals it away simply because there hasn't been such an original character for a long time. Nobody wants to cross THIS version of Pipi Longstockings!The story revolves around a locked-room/island mystery. An industrialist, Henrik Vanger, has life-long obsession with what really happened to his beloved niece, Harriet. Although  the Vagner family has no..shortage of bad apples, the mystery resisted to 40 years of thorough investigation by both the police and numerous private investigators. Blomkvist is persuaded to give it one last try not only by the substantial paycheck but also by the promise to be able to clear his name, tricked and convicted into libel as he had been.The Millennium Trilogy is Larsson's last gift to the world. reviewText: "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" builds on the legacy of many previous popular movies.  It could be described as a composite of Agatha Christie mysteries, "The DaVinci Code", "Hard Candy", "Silence of the Lambs" and the serial killer movies in toto,  "La Femme Nikita", and maybe even "Tank Girl"...but, to give credit where credit is due, it succeeds better than most of those predecessors.I believe the reasons for its success are good direction and a strong female lead performance by Noomi Rapace, who provides a stark counterbalance to the stuffiness of the other characters.  The locale of the movie provides a certain bracing freshness, with the beautiful Swedish countryside illuminated by cool blue hues and decorated with hoarfrost.The title character herself is a waifish, brilliantly paranoid creation--a comic book hero, an avenging female angel who answers any attack with a more ruthless, fierce comeback.  She is set in a corrupt world of technocrats, sadistic men, and a hierarchy of aging, fascistic capitalists who resemble a pack of vampires. Apparently this evil "coven" has sacrificed the only angelic presence in their midst, the beautiful Harriet, who is the mystery that the two detectives, combining their talents as journalist and computer hacker, must solve.It's good fun, extremely well-paced, and it keeps viewers hooked for two-and-a-half hours.  It doesn't really add up to a lot, but it seems to fit in with the zeitgeist of the times we live in.Though Daniel Craig will provide more charisma in the American version being filmed, I can't imagine that it will top this effort--no more than "Red Dragon" (speaking of tattoos) topped the earlier classic, "Manhunter".

reviewText: This is one of the few instances in which I can say that the film was better than the book.  Or, more accurately, less bad than the book. In the book, Blomquist was portrayed as a super-stud, who was so irrestable to women that many of them took their clothes off in his presence.  (I chalk this up to fantasizing on behalf of the writer who based Blomquist on himself.)  In the film Nyquist is much warmer, sweeter, more sensitive and actually made me care about him...enough to keep on watching.I liked the woman who played Lizbeth Salander, too, although I didn't relate to her at all in the book.  In the book, she's a one dimensional cartoon but in the film she manages to show some warmth and vulnerability behind the Goth and leather getup.  The original version of the film was Men who Hate Women and I think the change is much better.  This really is Lizbeth's film; she's the one we will remember.Other improvements:  some of Blomquist's sexual encounters with various women are left out, notably that with Berger, his boss at the magazine.  That was a relief!  Somehow the sexual assaults and various other crimes were less horrific here, although the film doesn't spare the sights.  Maybe it was because I knew what was coming, but also I think the book goes into much more details.I liked the relationwhip between Blomquist and Salander; I thought the film got it just right.  In the book it's much more about Berger, which is confusing.The story, itself, has possibilities.  Unfortunately much of it is beyond belief and way over the top in sensational garbage. reviewText: The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is, all at once, a taut and suspenseful action thriller, and an interesting study of human nature.A writer for Sweden's number one magazine, Mikael Blomkvist of Millennium, is facing a hefty fee of 150,000 kronor and a sentence to time in jail for slander and libel. Before his jail time is to happen, he gets a letter from Henrik Vanger, the head of a wealthy family. A man of 80, his niece had disappeared 40 years ago and was never found. He writes to Mikael asking him to help solve her mystery, and in turn, will help him out with the pickle he's in. So he moves to Hedestad, an island 3 hours away from Stockholm to get started on his work.A tattooed and pierced computer hacker named Lisbeth Salander has been following Mikael's case for quite some time. Lisbeth has Aspergers (or some sort of autism). She's sexy, but she's troubled- she's had a troubled childhood being in and out of behavioural centres. However, fate, or so it seems, leads Mikael to Lisbeth, where they both work together to solve this amazing case.This very film is why we go to the movies. At 152 minutes, your interest is held. It is a long movie, but the length is the last thing on your mind when watching it. Dragon Tattoo manages to keep you entertained, it immerses you in these awesome characters. They become your friends for 2 and a half hours, and the whole time you feel like you're solving the mystery with them.This film is full of suspense, and for its entire duration I was on the edge of my seat. Michael Nyqvist is just GREAT as Mikael, and everyone else is great, but the real highlight is Noomi Rapace. She is one of the most gorgeous and talented actresses out there right now. It struck me how so different she is in real life too- in this movie, she just IS Lisbeth. She is more than just a pretty face, she is an amazing actress, and it's such a shame that there aren't many actresses like her nowadays.In short, do not miss this flick. Even if you don't like foreign movies, do see this film. It is one of the greatest movies I've had the good fortune to see at the cinema, and a film that just improves with repeat viewings.

reviewText: I watched the original Swedish film The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo (translated The Man Who Hated Women) and it's amazing, after reading the book fairly recently, to watch this foreign adaptation.The original book was Swedish so it's appropriately a Swedish production.  Rather than Blomkvist the disgraced journalist who was the womanizer during his hiring by the Vanger Group to write a bio of the Vanger family as a front and then do the actual work of trying to solve a 40 year old murder case -- the disappearance of Harriet Vanger -- it was quite a different film!It's tough not to compare the book to the film but I'm glad to have watched the film regardless.  Gone is the womanizing, the affair with the married publisher of the magazine Millennium and gone is the cover story to write a bio of the Vanger family.The film is uneven at times.  The whole sexual predator guardian of Lisbeth (the girl with those tattoos) was faithful to the book.  The book though delved deep into her other guardian who helped her out at every turn.  The film skipped all that.Enough fat was cut from the book to make a smooth running mystery film without a lot of back story into the Vanger family, into Lisbeth's life or the sexual antics of Blomkvist.  At the time, the film was uneven and made enough changes to create a mildly disappointing adaptation.Hitchcock could take a mystery book and put his own twist to give an even better adaptation than the book would have fathomed.  On the other end of the scale, the director for Watchmen was too slavish in attempting to film every last panel of the graphic novel rather than cut out anything.In The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo, I would have liked more back story regarding the Millennium, the media's zealous hunt for a story, the commentary on financial markets and journalists -- and the extreme cleverness of Lisbeth.So much entertainment, but so much missing.  Rental!The book was better:The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
summary: Average Adaptation to this Swedish Thriller

reviewText: There are umpteen reviews of this movie so I won't further discuss  the plot in detail.This is a magnificent, richly detailed and emotionally moving film that offers a tremendous reward for those who stick with it and experience the climax. It's many related stories woven into one. This is not a movie to watch a bit at a time but rather, if you want to enjoy the emotion of the story,  you must be involved throughout the duration of the flickThere's a lot going on here. You have the woes of the title character, Lisbeth who is an abused ward of the State.You have an investigative trail pursued by a publicly defamed journalist, Michael. You have the reputation and exploits of Michael's small, investigative newspaper. You have debilitating secrets exposed of an aristocratic family and you have a fantastic disappearance mystery.The story is told in a slow moving yet highly absorbing manner. As the plot furthers, the mystery and eerie atmosphere steadily develops. The director does a very effective job by creating suspense through the prolonged use of old black and white photographs. During multiple times, there is simply the closeup of 40 year old portrait of the subject of the disappearance which is utilized in an effectively, spooky manner.This is a Swedish film with subtitles. The subtitles actually enhance the mysterious effect of the movie. It makes the viewer pay close attention to the dialog and excises any unwanted, unnecesary chatter. Part of the haunting charm of the movie involves the old world, European aura of many of the characters so the lack of English fosters this aspect perfectly (I cannot imagine this film being remade, which it is, by Hollywood, since I feel that taking away this "European" aura will take away what makes the film so interesting).Although there is action in the film, that is not what makes the film so good. The quality in the movie is not so much in the visual but rather in the quality of the story, the character development, and how it all resolves itself.This film gets better with repeated viewing since there is a lot to absorb. This is a fresh alternative to the mainstream.P.S. The other 2 films "The Girl who played with Fire" and "The Girl who kicked the Hornets Nest" are not merely sequels, they pick up EXACTLY where the preceding films end... although the three films are quite different from each other. To see one of the films before the other would be a mistake since each is predicated upon the earlier one. This film is a mystery, "Fire" acts as a "James Bond" like, spy piece and "Hornets Nest" is a courtroom drama. Each film is good but this first one is by far the best since it is quite an effective mystery.

reviewText: In response to those who understandably were distressed with this films violence:This film does not glorify rape and child molestation; it shows its ugliness and is a commentary on the victimization of women in our societies.  At the same time the lead female character Lisbeth Salander is a hero figure who refuses to play victim and pursues justice in an unjust society.Sometimes it is necessary for films to show graphic violence to make its point and have that emotional impact.  For example the Civil Rights movement was catupulted when Americans watched the news and were greeted with the horrific images of a sheriff grabbing an elderly black woman by the back of the neck and dragging her out of a voters registration line.  In this case the director had to be fictitiously graphic to have the same emotional impact.  Remember, the book in Sweden is called "Men Who Hate Women"; it would have been a great injustice to the subject matter if the violence was tame; indeed the tameness could very well have come across as condoning this behavior.This film also knew when and where to be graphic; the difference was "exploring" an issue versus "exploiting" it.  I don't recall any graphic visuals of child molestation or the murder of the women victims.  Instead we were given certain images to suggest these horrors.  Just like in Hitchcock's "Psyco" the violence is graphic at the beginning but thereafter violence is "suggested" and not displayed graphically.This film has ability to make the audience uncomfortable and entertaining at the same time; not an easy feat.

reviewText: When most Hollywood productions seem uninteresting and unoriginal (and mostly remakes * and they did a remake for this too), The Girl with The Dragon Tattoo comes as breath of fresh air from Sweden. I personally think this (and the entire trilogy) is one of the best cinematic events that came out of Europe in a long time.I've never read the book so I cannot compare. It only gets darker with addition of a troubled young girl with Gothic appearance and a dragon tattoo.The movie combines many various elements successfully, it is dark and very disturbing with elements of sexual abuse and torture creeping throughout the story at different levels - this is not a movie for the faint at heart. It is also a great mystery and has Sherlock Holmes' type of crime puzzle feel to it. It has some Hitchcockian elements, especially towards the end. The only bonus material is interview with Noomi Rapace which is quite interesting as she answers the questions with openness. If you think Noomi Rapace did a terrific job with her portrayal of this character, wait until you watch the interview - you will be even more impressed. She is absolutely nothing like the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo character. She is just a nice, sweet girl. I guess I've always imagined her to be similar to her character but I haven't seen an ounce of resemblance. This goes to show what a terrific performance she put. She talks about how she exercised for months, did kick-boxing to get in shape and learned to ride motorcycle.This version has original Swedish audio and also English dubbed-in audio.I personally prefer the Swedish film much better. reviewText: The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo is the first in the trilogy of crime novels written by Swedish journalist Stieg Larsson. Larsson wrote them during his spare time, as a form of amusement. However, the novels were not published until after Larsson's untimely death in Nov 2004. The author never had the opportunity to enjoy the critical and the commercial success his books eventually earned. In 2008 Larssen became the second best selling author on the planet.Now, on to the story:Mikael Blomkvist is a journalist, convicted, unjustly he believes, of libel against a powerful industrialist. As Blomkvist awaits the commencement of his sentence, he is hired by a scion of a wealthy family to investigate the disappearance of the man's bellowed niece 40 years earlier. Everyone, initially including Blomkvist, believes the case is hopeless. Unexpectedly though, help comes in form of "the girl with the dragon tattoo", Lisbeth Salander. The mysterious woman clearly has a severe past: despite being 24 years old, her person and finances are being managed by a court appointed guardian. She does however, have a brilliant mind and, as we are about to learn, a powerful will... She quickly becomes the driving force of the investigation. We watch transfixed, as the past reaches into the presence, and touches the lives of Blomkvist, Salander, her guardian, the industrialist and the wealthy scion.The story, as written by Larsson, is extremely brutal (consider that the original, and the very apt, Swedish title is "Men Who Hate Women"). However, I am inclined to believe the violence serves as another character in the story and as such is necessary. I am therefore glad that the filmmakers did not seek to tamper it, thus neutering the punch the story delivers. Though this Swedish adaptation is scripted and directed to the highest standard, the focus must be on the performance of the actress Noomi Rapace. Her portrayal of Lisbeth is shockingly faithful to the text and the actress manages to take over the film with her very appearance.The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo is one of the best adaptations I have seen, ever. I encourage you not to miss it; though do see it with friends, as you will afterwards feel strongly compelled to discuss the various explosive plot twists. I hope Hollywood never touches this gem. I am anxiously waiting for the next two installments to hit US screens.PS: Keep in mind, this film is NOT for the underaged.
summary: I'm still speechless... This will be a classic!

reviewText: So we all know that this is a Sweedish movie with English subtitles, right? And we all know that Director David Fincher will re-release an American version of the film next year with a completely different cast, right? And we all know that the movie(s) is based on the first of three books in a trilogy by Sweedish Author Stieg Larsson (RiP), right? And we all know that the original title of the book and movie were changed from Men Who Hate Women to The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo so that it would be more well received marketingwise in the US and not perceived as a bash against men by antisexism groups, right? And finally, we all know that the second film in the trilogy has already been released in Sweeden with less than positive reviews and the third in the trilogy will be released later this year...right?Whew. With all that out of the way, I thought The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo was great. Two story lines woven together nicely (albeit with the burden of reading subtitles from start to finish). The first story line follows Journalist Mikael Blomkvist after being convicted of libel for accusing a high powered businessman of gun running and other unethical and illegal activity. The widely publicized trial brings Blomkvist to the attention of another high powered businessman named Vanger looking for a long lost niece.Enter storyline 2: A Goth lady named Lisbeth works at a security firm that Vanger has hired to determine if Blomkvist is the right man to hunt for his niece. And the story arcs from there to the struggles of Lisbeth's everyday life of trying to make ends meet while on probation for some serious crimes committed in her relatively distant past.As I mentioned earlier, both stories are ultimately connected with each other in a thriller tale of intrigue, deception, mystery, murder and revenge. Actress Noomi Rapace plays Lisbeth with a seriousness that makes you think she's a real person out there somewhere, and that a camera followed her like a fly on the wall. And be warned, there are some scenes of rape and torture that are very unsettling and difficult to sit through in this film.I don't know why Fincher feels the need to re-do this movie in America, because the Sweedish version couldn't be more well done. It's a very good movie that stands on its own with no cliffhanger ending that requires seeing the upcoming sequels. Highly recommended but not for the squeamish.

reviewText: "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo," is a Swedish film based upon the huge international bestselling novel of the same nameThe Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (Vintage)by the late Swedish author Steig Larsson.  It is already in the pipeline for an American remake that will undoubtedly struggle to render the material cute and cuddly and good luck to the American filmmakers on that.  It's a mystery thriller about a disgraced journalist, Mikael Blomquist (Michael Nyquist) and a troubled young female computer hacker, Lisbeth Salander (Noomi Rapace) who are hired to investigate the case of an industrialist's favorite niece who disappeared 40 years ago and is presumed dead.Book and movie both boast a substantial amount of frank sexuality, and violence, much of it, misogynistic sadism, as seems to be not uncommon with contemporary Scandinavian authors; but they move fast, and are thoughtful and intelligent.  The movie, which was directed by Niels Arden Oplev, has so far earned an international box office of $90 million.  It has become the highest-grossing European film of 2009 and highest grossing Swedish film ever.The latter fact rather intrigues me, when you consider that means it has grossed higher than any of the many films of the late, great, much-admired, highbrow Swedish director Ingmar Bergman,Ingmar Bergman - Four Masterworks (Criterion Collection), and I can't help wondering whether this box office figure has been adjusted for inflation.  I also can't help thinking that Bergman must be turning over in his grave at this latest product from the Swedish film industry, though some of his films did have an element of violence.  Another interesting thought in regard to this statistic: the 1967 Swedish film,I Am Curious ...  (I Am Curious Yellow/I Am Curious Blue Set) - Criterion Collectionwas the movie that started the international porn trend, and was a pretty major blockbuster for its time: have the sales figures for this film been adjusted for inflation?  And, finally, "I Am Curious" was known in some locations as "Yellow Bird."  Among the production companies taking credit for "The Girl" is one known as Yellow Bird.  Are we then looking at an homage to "I Am Curious?"I read the book that underlies the movie a while ago, and my memory of it is no longer as sharp as it might be, but I am pretty sure that the book gives us no back story on Lisbeth, which the movie does: possibly this back story appeared in the second or third books Larsson wrote featuring Lisbeth?  I wonder about something else, too, being unable to remember it from the book: at a fraught point in the story, Lisbeth picks up a golf club to use as a weapon.  Who picked up that golf club first, Lisbeth, or Elin Nordegren, the Swedish model who married millionaire golfer Tiger Woods, and was driven to violence by his cheating ways ?  Of course, there were probably a lot of golf clubs lying around Elin's Florida mansion....Larsson, the late author, died suddenly in 2004 as a rather young man.  He left behind three unpublished novels, now known as the "Millennium" trilogy: they've become an international publishing sensation.  In 2008, Larsson was the world's second best selling author behind only "The Kite Runner's" Khaled Hosseini.  The first of these books was published in Sweden in 2005 as "Men Who Hate Women:"  it was published in the English speaking world under the title by which we know it; originally published in fall 2008 in the United States, it has gone on to sell nearly two million copies, making it one of the bestselling translated novels ever in the U.S.  Larsson was an investigative journalist and editor in chief of the Swedish muckraking magazine Expo.  He was one of the world's leading experts on anti-democratic, right wing fringe groups and neo-Nazi organizations; he often consulted and lectured on these subjects.  As a result, he reportedly lived for years under death threats from these people.Indeed, both book and movie appear to be the work of people who know what they are talking about - Mikael's and Lizbeth's findings, as they delve into the industrialist's family, have the ring of reality, and truth about them.  Mikael seems a bit of a wuss, but believe me, Lizbeth gives as good as she gets.  You might not want her as your sister or your daughter, but you'd want her on your side.  And you'd want to see her story, in the Swedish version.
summary: Lisbeth Gives as Good as She Gets

reviewText: How many times have we seen a terrific book eviscerated when adapted for the screen? Well, this is not one of those cases. While the movie does depart from the book at many points, it is faithful to the spirit of Stieg Larsson's dynamic novel.First off, the characters fit what I would expect of the two key protagonists--the journalist Mikael Blomkvist and the quirky Lisbeth Salander. Michael Nyqvist portrays "Kalle" Blomkvist in a most satisfying fashion. Indeed, as Salander refers to him in the novels, he is "Practical Pig" and an achingly well-meaning person. Noomi Rapace is Lisbeth Salander. If there is one role in this movie that cannot be compromised, it is Salander. The book's depiction of her calls for someone who is asocial, awkward in dealings with others, fully capable of violence, and not communicative. I wonder how Hollywood will depict Salander? However, in this movie version, Rapace is a revelation as the character. The movie (as the book) provides ample insight into how she has come to be not trusting of others (note her relationship to her new "guardian"). The actors, then, are part of what is critical to the success of this movie.Second, the plot is compelling. Blomkvist is sentenced to prison for libel, when he is duped into publishing erroneous information in an expose of a billionaire published in his magazine, "Millennium." Aged Henrik Vanger, after an investigation of Blomkvist by none other than Salander, wants to finally learn the fate of his granddaughter Harriett, who had disappeared/been murdered forty years earlier. Before his prison sentence commences, Vanger hires Blomkvist (in the book, much of this action takes place after the prison sentence, but the difference is a matter of no consequence as the movie is structured) to investigate the mystery. He begins his task, housed in an outbuilding on a gloomy island, populated by other Vangers (who appear to enjoy internecine battles one with another). After having hacked Blomkvist's computer as part of her investigation of him, Salander becomes interested in the murder of five women. After a sequence that, once more, departs from the book without affecting the dynamics of the story, the two partner in trying to solve the crimes and figure out what had happened to Harriett.Third, the cinematography is well done. The winter scenes almost made me shiver!The movie lasts 2 1/2 hours, but it did not seem that long at all. For me, the action rushed ahead, to the point where Blomkvist discovers who the villain of the piece is, to where he is saved from death by Salander, to her tracking the murderer. Again, this scene departs from the book but it might be even more satisfying here in terms of the drama, as Salander is not just witness to the murderer's death, but has some role in that death. We learn of the even more ghastly deeds of the murderer than what the two had originally discovered.While he is finally in prison, Salander sees Blomkvist one last time before she goes off to make her fortune. She gives Blomkvist the evidence he needs (from her ability to hack) to avenge himself against the billionaire who had duped him into actions leading to his stay in prison. reviewText: I think people who frequent foreign and independent films do so because they are looking for something different and unusual, something to challenge them, make them think, something to encourage discussion. Let's face it. Most of the studio films released can barely elicit more than a quick "It was okay". Or perhaps a terse "It sucked".I try to go to a fair number of these every year for these very reasons. Because I love to see films so much, I get sucked in by the hype of the big budget Hollywood films on a regular basis. And I frequently get disappointed. I need Foreign and independent films to provide an antidote to the cookie cutter fare usually perpetrated by the studios.But because American films are so popular worldwide, foreign filmmakers are struggling to find a market for their works, even in their own countries. The solution? Many are making their films more 'American'. Recently, the French thriller "Tell No One", based on an American bestseller, could easily have been the latest Michael Douglas thriller. In fact, I would be surprised if an American remake is not in the works. I think the film only worked as well as it did because the actors are French and spoke their native language throughout, somehow making it seem more intelligent. But the film is marred by an overly expository ending in which the guilty party explains at length how they committed the crime because there is basically no other way for us to know this happened. The film never gives us the clues we need to connect the dots.Now, the Swedish thriller "The Girl With A Dragon Tattoo", based on the international bestseller is a similar, better and more unusual film than "Tell No One".Mikael Blomkvist (Mikael Nykvist) is a disgraced journalist; his latest investigative target, a questionable billionaire has sued for liable and won, meaning Mikael must leave the magazine he started in order to save it. To occupy his time, he answers a query from a reclusive old man, Martin Vanger (Peter Haber), once a captain of industry, heading the company his family owned and operated, who now lives more or less as a recluse. Martin wants Mikael to find his niece, who disappeared under mysterious circumstances almost forty years ago. Mikael is reluctant, but a few mysterious photographs serve to pique his interest and he agrees to help.Lisabeth Salander (Noomi Repace) is a street-wise young woman very adept at computer hacking and finding people. She works at a detective agency finding people, making inquiries into their past, digging up dirt. Her inquiries into Mikael lead him to find out about her and he asks her to help him in his inquiries. She must be good to get past all of the firewalls protecting his information. She realizes this may be an opportunity to leave her abusive and violent past behind and agrees to help.As Mikael and Lisabeth begin their investigations, they quickly realize there may be more unexplained mysterious deaths connected and the scope of the investigation increases, becoming more dangerous.Before and during their investigations, they meet some people who are truly frightening. The film doesn't shy away from showing why these people are frightening (especially to Lisabeth) and these moments are a little hard to watch. But these same moments are also one of the aspects that set this film apart. An American film would never depict such brutality, could never depict such brutality and receive a wide release. Don't get me wrong. I think the brutality is necessary to the story, necessary to help us understand the type of character Lisabeth is. If it were simply gratuitous and didn't serve the story, "Dragon" would be a different beast altogether. But because it is a part of the story, it is necessary to experience these moments. Without it, the film would seem hollow and very artificial.All of this is good and all of this adds up to precisely what makes independent and foreign films so interesting to me, so vital a part of my movie going regimen.My problem with "Dragon Tattoo" comes in the last few moments. Much like a bad American thriller, or a television show, the identity of the people responsible is revealed through lengthy discourse from the guilty party themselves. They tell a story revealing all, who, what, when, where, how. And much of it doesn't make sense or add up because we simply aren't given the details. Any details we are given are so buried within the confusing and multi-layered narrative it almost seems like this dialogue is needed to help tie up the loose ends.When writers resort to this method of discourse, it just seems sloppy. If you are writing the film, you have the license to do whatever you want. Make it believable enough and the reader (and watcher) will go with you. I can't comment on whether the book follows this same road because I haven't read it. Given the success of the book, I have to think the screenwriters who needed to streamline the story a bit did this. They cut out some scenes and as a result had to 'tie everything' up in the end."The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is interesting and unusual enough to satisfy the serious cinephile's foreign film bug. I just wish they had been able to come up with a better, more unusual way, tying up the story's loose ends, providing these same viewers with a truly memorable ending. As it stands, it is little better than the ending of an episode of "Murder She Wrote".The remaining two books in the trilogy have already been made into films in Sweden. An American remake is already in the works from director David Fincher ("Seven", "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button"). If anyone is able to retain the violent, unusual nature of the story, Fincher seems a good choice. Brad Pitt is a strong candidate for the male lead. It will be interesting to see how this strange hybrid foreign film translates to an American made film.

When the pair link Harriet's disappearance to a number of grotesque murders from almost forty years ago, they begin to unravel a dark and appalling family history. But the Vangers are a secretive clan, and Blomkvist and Salander are about to find out just how far they are prepared to go to protect themselves.I am a big fan of suspense novels and films, and this was the movie that really stunned my visual perspective. The story will keep you engaged wether you have read the book or not. The flow of the film is kept faithful to the book, this is rare when it comes down to book to movie adaptations. One of the best things about this movie was that the story does not drag, it does have anything in it that's not necessary. In fact, you need to pay attention to every little thing, because every little thing does have some connection with the climax of the film, including its chilling twist.ACTINGNoomi Rapace as Lisbeth Salander was terrific, she was tough, she fit the role perfectly. I can tell Noomi really got into the role. She is by far my favorite book/movie character simply because her character is so intense, we learn about her past until the end. Michael Nyqvist as Mikael Blomkvist was fantastic, a very thrilling actor. Everyone's acting was great, and I would go on and on about all the great performances that were given, but I'll just leave it at that.FILTERSI really liked the filter used to make the film, it was dark, and it left a tense atmoshpere.FINAL WORDGreat show, great show! They were able to incorporate every detail that the book had, nothing seemed rushed. As I said earlier, I have yet to see the daniel craig version, but I can't imagine hollywood mastering this masterpiece. I will watch that version as well, I also can't wait to see how they did "The girl who played with fire" and "The girl who kicked the hornets nest." They were all great stories. I highly recommend you to see this movie, fans of the book will be pleased, even if you haven't read the book, you're gonna love this!
